This was a tiny bit of an issue, because we ordered the chef's choice; this means they clear the used plates and bring the next course about 10 times. so our privacy was a bit invaded. the food was surreal. everything tasted better than i could have ever imagined. the fiesta roll: to die for. the regular makes, were just regular, and very fresh. the specialty rolls are so fresh and so expertly made, the tastes are superb. The price was not outrageous and we felt so pleased with our meal and the portions. it was worth it. I cannot wait for the next special occasion that will take us back. stellar menu, nice ambience, and overall amazing dining experience.

LOVE cozy little - off the beaten path places with great food, attentive staff and interesting decor.

Stopped by Kai Zan on a Sunday evening, without a reservation, and waited about 10 minutes for a table.  Next time I'll either make a res., or for the spur of the moment cravings, pick up the phone and pray - because I'm guessing, as word gets out, short 10 minute waits may be a thing of the past.

There were two of us, and for less than $40 we sampled:

Escolar Pearls
Angry Crab
Orange Crush
Specialty Roll of the night - name escaping me - three different types of tuna and a kick
Spicy Octopus
Hamachi / Jalapeno

Flavors were wonderful and soy sauce was only needed for the hamachi.  If I was forced to pick a favorite ... it would have to be the Orange Crush (which was a surprise from one of the chefs towards the end of our meal) or the Angry Crab.

Thank you Kai Zan for a superb end of the weekend meal.  I will be seeing you again soon!

This place was sweet.  It's in a very nondescript area.. you wouldn't know it's there just walking by.  It's BYOB, and there's a minimart right across the street.  So we bought 2 bottles of cold sake and brought it over.  Once you walk inside, you know it's going to be good.  Pretty hostess, hipster servers, clean/modern decor, personal asianstyle booth-rooms.  We sat in one and it's nice.  Immediately a server brought over warm towels to wash our hands and a bucket of ice for our cold sake and sake glasses.  Most of us got the Omakase, and it was Omakawesome.  Basically it's the $60 tasting menu.  It was probably 12+ dishes, and it was soooo much food and very good.  I can't remember it all, but that wasn't the point.  The point is they're bringing out a lot of yummy food fast and furious you just eat it.  I love that way of eating.  It was a lot of sushi favs like sashimi and rolls and carpaccio, and other raw items like oyster shooters, uni shooters w/ raw quail egg, and also yakitori type things like grilled mackerel, octopus salad, grilled mussel, fried jalapeno, bacon wrapped enoki mushrooms, and then other random stuff like a crab dish, mushroom dashi, etc.  There were several other dishes as well.  It's a lot of food.  They don't try and overcomplicate the dishes w/ a ton of ingredients and flavors, but they do make some of the more unique dishes interesting.  

Service was great and the dishes came out quick and plates cleared and dishes were described and they checked up on the one person in our party who didn't order the omakase.  

I'd recommend this place to anyone!
Brilliant, succulent sushi in a Midwestern city.  Impossibly great.  A triumph.

The other reviews are all spot on: (1) omakase is the way to go; (2) make sure you have the escolar pearls; (3) unagi poppers are as ridiculously amazing as they sound; (4) the service is questionable and they definitely want you to eat and GTFO.

That sums it up.

Took my mom here for her bday. For a Tuesday early dinner we still need a reservation. The place is teeny tiny but feels airy and light. Our server was awesome and the food was killer. Took other yelpers advice and got the Escolar Pearls. I can't wait to get them again. The oyster shooters with quail egg and fly fish roe was also great. There's a ton on the menu I can't wait to go back for. I am treating my boyfriend to this place next week, mostly cuz I want more for myself!

This to me is the best sushi in town.  I've been here several times.  The restaurant is full of the family that owns the restaurant and they seem to take a lot of pride in what they do.  I recommend the pearls (I like escolar a little better than the tuna), orange crush and angry crab.  Everything else is really good too, but those are my favorites.

First visit to Kai Zan and definetly not the last. My boyfriend was recommended by one of his fellow firefighters. He knew that I love sushi and in our three years together we had never gone for sushi as a couple, he never has had sushi. First of all, the staff was friendly, gracious and very helpful when it came to ordering and questions on what we were about to eat. We ordered the Omakase for $60, worth every penny.  My boyfriend and I did not have much conversation relating to anything other than the food that was put in front of us and into our mouths.  We will be back, soon!
this place is awesome i don't think i can go back to low quality sushi. this is a palates dream.  i can't wait to come back

I've been meaning to try this restaurant for a while.  I am always on the lookout for good sushi places of all types.

The decor was interesting, without being flashy, stuffy or kitsch.  I thought the place has a nice, homey feel from the second I walked in.  Strangely shaped, small and a bit cramped, but interesting, with some nice semi-private areas and not too loud.

We tried a huge variety of sushi rolls and a few other dishes.  The kaki fry was an awesome version.  3 massive, juicy oysters with a nice, thin and crisp coating. We also tried a special of mixed mushrooms and tofu steamed in sake that was really delicious.  We enjoyed the rolls quite a bit.  The fish was fresh, presentation beautiful, and the special combinations were not heavy handed.

We enjoyed the service as well.  Our server was knowledgable and accessible, and our water was filled and empty plates removed in a timely fashion.

As for value, the place is not cheap, but not overpriced either.  We spent just over $90 for two including tip, but we really pigged out.  You could do it for $50-60 most of the time, which is about what I'd spend at Coast or similar places.  Portion size was decent in most cases, although a few of the specialty rolls were only 2 pieces, which for $8 is pretty small.

Overall, a great experience and I'll be returning very soon.

I agree with some of the other reviews.  The bad outweighs the good.
We felt rushed, omakase was poorly timed (i.e. 2-3 dishes at a time, server trying to take my plate away while I'm still eating).  Plus, I don't think the food is that creative or tasty.  Spicy mayo on everything. The flavor profile is pretty one-tone and the condiments (i.e. mayo, chili oil, tabasco, etc etc) take away from the freshness and the flavor of the seafood itself.  A good example of this would be the uni that was drowning in ponzu.  I did really appreciate that the seafood was fresh.  And I thought the decor of the place was awesome with its private booths!

Sensational sushi - fresh, wonderful flavors and very interesting options.  Not the overwhelming menu or over the top flavors. which often means no real flavor, of so many other places.  Our favorites are the Maguro pearls, Danielle and Angry Crab, and the Fiesta roll.  Also the different skewers are wonderful, particularly the different veggie options such as Shitake or asparagus.

The restaurant is quite small but a very nice atmosphere.  Hard to get a reservation but worth it.
Best tasting and most creative sushi I've had in Chicago. Unagi shooters and black sesame ice cream lava cake are a must, but you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.

Not a big raw fish fan but there are plenty of other dishes to choose from. Excellent Excellent Excellent. Atmosphere is intimate, casual, and cozy. Service was just right. We shared a few rolls and skewers. My fav was the fiesta roll. Everything is fresh with the right amount of spice.

Had green tea ice cream for desert. Prices were reasonable. A very pleasant suprise for living 2 blocks away. Make reservations ahead of time!

Dined at Kai 7/24/14.

Despite the fact that I had heard amazing things about this restaurant, I was apprehensive after making my reservation, which I made online day of.  Over the course of my day, I was reminded multiple times, either in writing or verbally from restaurant staff (when calling to confirm) that my table was mine from 7-9pm.  I am comfortable giving my credit card number to book a reservation, but, as an industry worker, this is something I have never heard before.  Would I be rushed?  Might my Omakase be cut short?  What if I want dessert?  They did a very good job of instilling a sense of urgency and time into my mind (as I'm sure was intended) before even arriving at the restaurant.

However, my fears were unfounded.  We arrived about 15 minutes early and were seated instantly in what I believe to be the newer area.  We sat in a luxuriously large and private booth meant to accommodate up to 6 I assume.  There were five of us and we had a TON of space to spread out.  Still feeling a little bit like we might need to hurry, we wasted no time in a ordering.  We actually ordered all of our food BEFORE discussing beverage, just to be safe.

Between the five of us, four had Omakase and one ordered from the menu.  Someone (the kitchen or our server Abby) did  a wonderful job making sure that our lone ranger was fed in a way that timed very well with the rest of us eating Omakase.  

So I don't have to say it over and over, we found all of our fish to be of the highest quality.

I can't remember everything that I ate from the Omakase, but most of it has been previously mentioned here on yelp.  I can, however, say that we tried all but one of the daily specials.  We skipped the Lamb Pops (although I'm sure they were delicious) and started with the Scallop Sashimi, which we were told was freshly shucked, to order, from live scallops.  So clean tasting.

Also we enjoyed Otoro tartare over rice with a quail egg, wasabi, some truffle and three MONSTROUS Uni lobes.  

Finally the fried Aji, a mild mackerel.  So cool.  They served about 6-8 slices of Sashimi from the Aji, inside of the Aji.  The fish itself was fried, but because it has soft bones (like a softshell crab?) you can eat the whole fish.  I've had whole fish before, and I what they plate usually looks like in the end.  This was not that.  We were served a whole fish, and returned plates with no debris.  Awesome.

We followed this with Omakase.  All I will say is that it feels to me like a steal.  At $60, you can't afford NOT to have it!  I would happily pay another 40-60 if Carlo and Melvin maybe added a Wagyu course, maybe used some fresh truffle instead of oil, I don't know.  I thought it was wonderful.

After Omakase, we wanted to try some of the grilled skewers.  We were pretty filled up, but we had some time left on our table! Good thing we ordered quickly.  We tried the beef tongue, duck, pork belly shishito peppers.  The pepper were wonderful as well with ponzu (?) and bonito flakes.  We commented to our server that we felt the Uni was of an especially high quality and the kitchen sent for us the Escolar Pearls (oysters wrapped in escolar) each topped with another HUGE Uni lobe over a tobasco and ponzu foam as our final bite. THANKS CARLO AND MELVIN. A rich end to a rich meal.  

All in all, we never felt rushed during the meal, loved everything we ate and look forward to bringing the rest of our friends back.  Everyone should hurry up and go before they get their Michelin star and Carlo and Melvin realize they are shortchanging themselves on price, because they are.

Had the omakase.  It was well worth it.  Service was great.  Great value at $50, lots of food, a great variety of flavors.  One of the beat Japanese-style restaurants i've been to in a long time.  Will definitely be back!
Amazing sushi taken to the next level. Not just your standard rolls. Do the uni shooter. Regardless of your past experiences with uni, you'll become an immediate fan.

Came here to celebrate with some friends. The server recommended the tasting menu, which was $60/person, telling us it was a great value for the money. The skeptic in me thought it was a great up sell, but we all opted for the tasting menu anyway. We were not disappointed. 10 courses, everything ranged from good to amazing. They were also very conscientious about all the various dietary restrictions for our party. Wonderful sushi, byob, and the private booths (if you can get them) are great!

A bit over priced. Got the fried calamari appetizer assuming that a high end sushi restaurant would cook it properly. It was horribly chewy and tiny thin pieces of calamari, so it was like eating mostly breading. The green monster roll and fiesta roll were very good, but much more expensive than you can get elsewhere. The restaurant set-up and decor look very nice though.

I am a huge fan of sushi and so when my foodie friend told me about Kai Zan and showed me the delectable pictures of uni nigiri I immediately made room in my schedule and prepared myself for lots of uni.

But then we got there and could NOT find parking for the longest time. It was terrible---we ended up being 15 minutes late and they told us that we only had an hour and 15 minutes left to eat and so we better hurry. We had known about the hour and a half policy and tried our hardest to be on time but traffic and parking had worked against us that day. So we started out our meal totally frazzled and squeezed ourselves into the bar where my friend proceeded to order the omakase (because it looked delicious and didn't require making more decisions based on our time restraints). It was a lot of food and she really enjoyed it. Her favorites were definitely the amazing mussels that were broiled with some kind of sauce and the angry crab and orange rush sushi.

I agreed with all of these assessments since the angry crab and orange rush were basically perfect little bites of food (their special nigiri) that were packed with flavor! I also loved the maguro pearls and escolar pearls. We were both disappointed to hear that they were out of uni that night but we still ended up having a delicious meal. The sushi was very fresh and cut well but a lot of the flavors seemed to keep repeating themselves (seemed to be a reliance on truffle oil and spicy mayo (though in moderation). Also we definitely kept checking our watches to see when we would get "kicked out". What made this more frustrating was the fact that our server disappeared for a long time near the later part of our meal and we were trying to order dessert while we still had time. But then when she returned she told us not to worry about going over our time and brought out our desserts with only 5 minutes of our hour and 15 remaining. So that was nice but we definitely would have preferred them to reassure us that there would be enough time since we felt rushed the whole meal...

This a cozy and beautifully decorated restaurant. But I did not come here for just the decor!  I was really looking forward to trying Kai Zan but unfortunately it fell short of my expectations. The best part was the escolar pearls. They are truly little bursts of deliciousness!  But they are LITTLE!  The sashimi pieces were just alright, nothing to write home about. The husband said the tuna and octopus were fresh...but in general this place is mediocre in my book, considering the price and lack of super fresh sushi.  I would rather go to Lawrence fish market and get fresher sushi for much cheaper, and eat it in the comfort and mediocre ambience of my own home.
Best sushi in Chicago.  The fish is so fresh and delicious.  Seriously, the quality of the fish is amazing and the place is clean.  So happy to have found this place!

I love what these guys are doing. They have been passionate & hardworking for years. Now on their own the twins are truly shining. The omakase is so good it truly blew me away. The quality of both food & skill will make you smile. Being able to walk here makes it even better for me. I didn't want to keep spreading the word because I never don't want to be able to get in, but this whole place is amazing so I had to keep word spreading of the succulent splendor they create. All the best see you soon.

Insanely good.  Tonight we had the $90 Tasting Menu.  There is a $60 tasting menu but tonight there was a special offering and it was worth it.  I have had Uni a lot and heard it described as the "foie gras of the sea".  I have never thought of Uni as foie gras ish but tonight was the first time I have had it so fresh that is melted on my tongue and it was amazing and did have a foie grasness about it.  Maybe two courses were good, the rest were great or insanely good.  The service was fast and knew their food.  I have been to Koi in L.A., Blue Ribbon in NYC and Pod in Philly and this place smokes them all (better then Koi is not saying much, L.A. hype b.s.).  This is an absolute must.  Good luck on the reservations though!

I use Yelp regularly for recommendations, but only write reviews if I am blown away (good or bad).  This place BLEW ME AWAY!  I have never tasted anything quite like the dishes they prepared and presented.  My husband and I ordered the chef's tasting menu ("omakase") and I am so glad we did.  We got to sample so many amazing creations such as oyster and quail egg shooters, a caramelized scallop skewer, and chocolate lava cake with black sesame seed ice cream (I think!).  These are just a few of the creative and perfectly executed tastings that were placed before us.  This is a must for everyone to try - sushi lover or not.  In fact, the sushi is a mere filler on a menu like this!

GO!!!!!

Best affordable modern Japanese restaurant I've been to in Chicago.  

We got the Omakase and it was delightful.  My favorites were the escolar pearls and the salmon belly sashimi.  But when you get the Omakase, you just get the best of everything.  So there is no need to order by taking people's recommendations on Yelp.

The ambiance is beautiful.  We sat in the sunny little patio up front but the wood interior is gorgeous.  I hope to sit in a booth next time.  One of the twin brother owner chefs walked around to ask us if we enjoyed our meal.  The wait stuff was attentive and you can tell they love their food as well.  As they should.  Its so good.  Make a reservation now.

A couple people have told me about Kai Zan and after going I can see why. It is amazing!  The sushi is so fresh you can really taste the fish. It specializes in little bites more along the lines of nigiri and sashimi rather than huge rolls with lots of spicy mayo. So if that is what you like do NOT come here. We ordered so much it is hard to remember everything, but my favorites were the escolar pearls and the angry crab sushi! Beyond amazing! One thing to know is that it is BYOB for everything. I wanted a coke but they informed me that they only have water and green tea, but if you forget he mentioned a store across the street where you can get your libation of choice. It is also a bit hard to find. The sign is very small, blink and you miss it. But it is so worth it once you find it! Enjoy!

Kai Zan is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago! The food is fantastic and the ambiance is perfect for a tiny BYOB.  I've had the chef's tasting menu and I've ordered off the menu a la carte. I even grab food to go when I'm feeling lazy.  The staff has only gotten better with time.  This is great place for a foodie who doesn't want to break the bank! This restaurant is making my neighborhood a better place to live and visit! Thanks so much Kai Zan- you guys are killing it!
Flaming tuna app was one of the best things i've ever had.   Good Maki, not great but everything else made up for it.  The duck skewer was awesome.  when I go back I'll try more skewers

We both ordered the 10 course Omakase market price. It was fantastic. I'm too tired and full of awesome food to remember all the dishes perfectly but will focus on the highlights. All of the fish was superb. Stated. Second course was bar none my favorite- an oaky smoked mackerel served in a cold liquid nitrogen smoking granite bowl thing. K. Other things of note: a 'cappuccino' style broth dish- foamed top that you sip with shaved truffle-  with 3 small neck clams in the bottom- yay! The wagyu beef was buttery melty (I'm not a big beef person and it was nice). Fatty tuna surfaced a few times in the courses (nigiri and sashimi) can't go wrong there. The sea urchin came out served between tempura sesame leaves which I had never had before- like a little labia it tasted weirdly like the ocean as it should. Edible flowers throughout. Oh! and they ferment their wasabi and serve coarsely chopped in a saucy consistency rather than as a paste- lovely. Many complicated broths and sauces. We loved it.

This place is really great, one of my favorite sushi places in the city and I'm a snob about sushi. Considering the quality of the fish-which was excellent-the menu is very fairly priced. My friends and I were sat in a cabana, the service was great, the ambiance comfortable and it's BYOB. Check it out!

Omakase all the way.  My brother lives by here and  told me about the omakase, but unfortunately for him his wife is not as adventurous with food so they ordered off the menu.  The only downfall which is minor is that we were sat right next to the window so any time the door opened it was cold, but a small price to pay for the phenomenal culinary experience.  

The ambiance of the restaurant is ideal--I kind of felt like I was at a spa.  Great for date night and you can't beat the quality, creativity and presentation of the food.  Will definitely be going back!

Best sushi restaurant in Chicago in my opinion.  Love that it's BYO, love the new addition for more seating and to accommodate larger groups, and I love the specials and creativity of the chefs.  The fish is fresh and the rolls are inventive, I could eat the Maguro Pearl appetizer every day!

(psst: i have a 7:45 pm reservation tonight, 12/19 for 4 that i can't use. friend/message me if you can use the table)
___________________________________

incredible sushi. truly. not what you expect for sure, not from the neighborhood, maybe not from the exterior, just go with an open mind. and don't order a california roll--this is the place to be adventurous because it's all insanely good. at some point in the meal you will gasp and look around and try and figure out if what you're experiencing is real. it's *that* good, people.

I found Kai Zan on Yelp and was intrigued by the great reviews. However, I was not thrilled by their sushi. It wasn't bad, just average. I would give another place a shot before going back to Kai Zan. On the other hand, the décor and atmosphere are great, very clean and modern. Also, the BYOB feature is awesome!

4 visits and enjoyed all of them.   This place is great!  I would suggest something to try specifically, but everything is well made so you really can't go wrong.  

Just make a reservation early as the place is tiny and there aren't enough tables to go around if you are a walk in.

Great hidden gem and BYOB sushi spot.  A little off the beaten path but food was excellent.  Make a reservation because it's very small and you will have to wait.  The green monster was an awesome sushi roll and I would definitely get it again.  Escolar pearls were also good but I wouldn't have to get them again.  Overall great date spot and great sushi.

I came here for dinner with my daughter this past Tuesday, she had heard of the place but it was a first time visit for both of us.  The first thing that strikes you is its small, intimate size and setting (making reservations a must).  For its size (and the fact that it was packed during our visit) it is remarkably conversation friendly.  We were seated right on time and never felt rushed.

Kai Zan is BYOB with limited non-alcoholic drink options so be prepared. We used it as an opportunity to choose a few extra items from the menu in lieu of cocktails. My choice was the unagi poppers that, although he waiter tried to persuade me against as "not unique", I thoroughly enjoyed.

A few general words about the menu.  Small and well chosen.  It is the size of an single sheet of paper offering a broad, but still select group of options.  It was nice to not have to wade through page after page of "house specialties".

What we both found unusual was the preparation of the rolls.  There seems to be a trend to over sauce to the point of losing the flavor of the fish in current soy/wasabi blends.  Not so here.  It has been a long time since I enjoyed such a great balance between the ingredients.  Very refreshing....and yes, the Escolar Pearls and Angry Crab are must tries.  All of our choices were both flavorful and delicate simultaneously though sometimes the construction required a light touch on the chopsticks lest your bite disassembles on its way to your mouth.  I had the mango pudding for dessert, also a winner.

Prices are very reasonable though portions are just a bit on the small side.  It did allow for a nice sampling experience and now that I think back I would describe the meal as sushi meets tapas.  The two of us left fully satisfied for $75 (not including tip).

The service was good with an exception of a miscalculation on our server's part at one point overwhelming our small table.  In a small sushi restaurant with a lot to sample, timing is everything.  

I will go back to sample the great food  in one of the four cozy, enclosed dining booths on the left side of the restaurant. They looked like a great date/anniversary setting.

Unfortunately the recent expansion has taken it's toll.  I dont think that the small kitchen is dealing well with three times the diners.  Omakase rounds are ill timed...temperatures are mostly all now room.temperature.... service is less personal and consistent.  The raise in the omakase price would be justified if the food hadn't taken such a hit in quality.  Lastly, and most alarming... sashimi is a bit warm, texture is off, and pieces are cut peculiarly small.  The angry crab is still spot on...amazing...so good...as if a seperate chef is responsible for that one dish.  Sorry guys. Gotta be honest.  You were one of my faves... lots has changed.

Our favorite sushi place in Chicago, by far. Been here 15-20 times. The Omakase is legit. Great combination of flavors and textures. Very happy they expanded and can seat more... More opportunities to enjoy now. Also love leaving a restaurant with only a $100 tab for two.. Doesn't happen often in Chicago.

Angry crab made us so happy.  Everything else was equally as great!  The only thing that made me sad was that my stomach wasn't larger.  They do it right!  Welcome to the neighborhood!  I just hope I can still get a table once the rest of the city catches on to this tiny space full of amazing!

I almost don't want to tell people about this place it's so good.  There are only like 18 tables so make a reservation.  It's really tight in there but totally worth it.  The sushi is really tasty and unique!  It's expensive, but makes up for the cost of the food b/c it's BYOB!  There's a liquor store on the corner that sells sake too!

Although I was looking for a pure Omakase experience (aka, fish only), however, I probably found one of the best Kaiseki places in Chicago. The food, the creativity and the flavor here is great. At a price of 50 bucks, Kai Zan is a steal for the kind of food you get.

Although I'd go back and just order the fish and nothing else, just to have a pure omakase experience.

Look, all I can tell you is that I rarely give 5 stars.  This place is as good as it gets in Chicago.  It's that damn good.  Go, NOW, before you die... your soul will wander the spirit world forever if you don't go, haunting your family, wondering WHY DIDN'T I GO TO KAI ZAN FOR THE BEST DAMN SUSHI IN CHICAGO?  WHY? WHYYYY????  

It ain't cheap, but great fresh seafood never is.

The food here is delicious.  Any of their special sushi items are highly recommended. This is what we ate:

Appetizers:

- Maguro Pearls:  These were so good, reminiscent of the 8-ball at Kyoto, where the chefs used to be.

- Tonkatsu with shiso: very good, although just a touch dry.

Kushi:

- Momo:  Perfectly cooked and juicy, although unseasoned.  The sauce was good, but the chicken needed salt.

- Shrimp negi mayo:  Again perfectly cooked and fresh, although not mind-blowing.

- Shitake:  These are meaty and have a great sauce.  I don't like mushrooms, but these were given to us by the itamae so I went for it.  Not bad, but nothing to write home about.

Nigiri:

- Mackerel:  Although the fish was tough, the fresh grated wasabi on this really stood out.  It was bright and citrusy, with a touch of heat but not the overly-artificial flavor of wasabi paste.  

Makimono:

- Yellowtail Scallion:  At too many places a roll like this is bland and boring.  Not here.  The rice doesn't overpower, but complements the fish very well.  You can taste each ingredient independently, which is much more than 99% of the sushi places in Chicago can say, where a makimono tastes almost completely of bland rice.

Kai Zan Sushi (this is where Kai Zan really shines):

- Danielle Sushi:  A perfect little bite.  A bit spicy, a bit sweet, and very fresh tuna.  I'd also order this each and every time I visit Kai Zan.

- Orange Rush Sushi:  A seared piece of salmon with a great citrus glaze, wrapped around a very delicate scallop.  I'm not typically a salmon fan, but I'd also order this each and every time I visit Kai Zan.

- Angry Crab Sushi:  Another great piece of tuna with a great sauce.  I couldn't necessarily distinguish the crab, but with tuna so good, it's hard to fault this one.  Likely another "order every timer"

- Flaming Tuna Roll:  As much as we love fresh fish, every once in a while we like to splurge on an Americanized fried with lots of sauce roll.  This was it, and was a great representation of one.  Shrimp tempura was crunch inside, with

Dessert:

- Green tea ice cream with red bean:  The red bean was interesting - my only experience with red bean is with red bean mochi, and the red bean here was much more savory than sweet.  The green tea ice cream was very good, and complemented the red bean well, but I'd likely pass on this in the future as it wasn't all that impressive.

- Mango mousse:  Not on the menu, but was a special.  This was more like a custard than a mousse, but was light, not overly sweet, and a good way to finish a meal.  I likely wouldn't order it again, but for those who like light custardy desserts (not sure how that works, but that's the best way I can describe it), you could do worse.

Observations:

Service was good and friendly.  We sat at the sushi bar, where the itamae would check to make sure everything was satisfactory.  Our server was not intrusive, even in a tight space such as it is.  They absolutely need to do something about the fryer on the line...we sat at the bar and all we could smell was the oil, which was a bit unappetizing.  I also love sitting at the sushi bar and watching the itamae work.  You can't do that here, as their hands are hidden from view by the fish cooler.  I'd suggest moving the fryer to the back (I don't think they have room...) and rearranging the bar so that people can feel a connection with the itamae, especially if you opt for the omakase.

Went last night with another couple. I wish I had thought to track how many times we said "wow". We all did the 10 course Omakase menu and were so glad we did.  We felt like you got a lot of sushi for $60 and everything was awesome.  We were seated in one of the private booths and were very happy with it.  I am not a food geek who wants to try every new and fancy and expensive restaurant but I am dying to go back and get the other chef's choice Omakase. Last night it was $120 and my experience with the $60 one just made me curious as to what else the chef will come up with.  Bravo!

So glad to have the Twins back! I've always said I love Sushi, but really its what the Twin's do with sushi.  Their preparation is unique, fresh, and amazing.  There is no place that compares.  My friends and I always let the chef's decide what to serve us and have never been disappointed.  I highly recommend going this route. Can't wait to try some more of their new items.  The space is fantastic and shows off the heart and soul they put into creating it.

Sushi restaurants in Chicago are a dime a dozen. This is the best sushi I have had the pleasure of eating in Chicago.  Fresh, melt in your mouth good with an amazing balance of flavors. (No soy sauce needed!) To top it off the staff was friendly, the decor is adorable, the prices are great and byob...Kai Zan, I'm in love!
I can't say anything bad about this place.  It's truly a hidden gem.

Love the layout and the convenience near my stomping grounds. The sushi is presented like art. The rolls are delicious and cheap. Skewers are great, especially the scallop one. Byob. Will definitely be back regularly.
The sushi was amazing - some of the best I've had. Only a few selections for Maki rolls but they were delicious. MUST get the two Pearls apps. My only regret was not getting more Pearls.

Great sushi experience, felt like going to someone's home (when you visit, you will know what I mean; it looks and feels like a house) and being served with such care and importance. We did the $50 tasting menu. Each dish was a new  and fun experience. We marveled at the artistry of the presentation and dove into the delights. Each dish was paced almost perfectly.  Just as we finished one dish, enjoyed some saki and conversed, the next one arrived. A cycle repeated that at one point it seemed it would never end. The only thing stopping us was our full bellies. We had a reservation (recommended) but sat at the sushi bar, which happened to be directly in front of the both chefs. I noticed they were so interested and attentive to how we reacted to their creations, watching carefully out of the corner of their eyes. The moans, oohs and aahs brought a slight smile of great satisfaction and pride to their faces, knowing that they had succeeded in delighting us. Can't wait to return.  どうもありがとうございます Doumo arigatou gozaimasu. Thank you very much!!!

Omakase! I got to say...Kai Zan has leaped into my top 10 restaurants in Chicago and I'll definitely be coming back.

Fresh fish, creative preparation, and great service.

My wife and I had a fantastic date at Kai Zan.  We ended doing both of the omakase (both the Chefs Choice ($60) and the premium ($100, cost varies each night)). Both were amazing. The only downside of ordering both was occasionally there were one-bite plates. Not a big deal though. The food was incredible. The service was also great. Both meals were 10 courses. Highlights were the cold smoked fish served in a small stone bowl, scallop wrapped with wagyu beef, perfectly cooked pork that somehow tasted like foie gras, and a huge plate of sashimi. The classic omakase was incredible and I would highly recommend. If you're thinking about going for the premium, its well worth it.  There was a discrete bump in quality and presentation, although both were great. I would certainly recommend and will come back again someday.
Got takeout from this place and it was Oh so delicious!!! I usually stick to the California rolls at other Sushi places, but I felt comfortable trying new bites here and I was not disappointed.

My wife and I went o Kai Zan tonight and had to write a review ASAP.  We have been to just about every sushi restaurant in Chicago and have a new favorite.  Kai Zan is terrific.  The sushi is flown in fresh daily and is evident from the very first bite.  The manager grew up in Japan on the waterfront and was charming and knowledgeable.  The twin owners/chefs came by our table to say hello and are clearly proud of their work.  Go to Kai Zan and you will not be dissapointed.  This was an easy 5 star review.

Hands down the best sushi that I've had the pleasure of eating in Chicago.  Superb service by our server Michelle.  Angry Crab was great, as were the little Escolar Pearls.  I felt that prices were creeping toward the high side, but the quality was extremely high, so therein lies the trade-off.  I feel like I'd like to have a standing reservation once a week here, it's that good.  Nom, nom!

Hands down best sushi I've had in the city. I defy anyone to dislike this place after eating there. Its amazingly good. After our 1st time dining there we went back the next night. When we were seated and other tables were leaving they were making reservations to come back the next night. Staff is great, I love the fact that it is a itsy bitsy little restaurant. I love that it is out of the way. Great menu and a lot of specials that are super yummy and change frequently. I'll be back again and again. Try the angry crab, best plate I had this year,

We went here for the first time last weekend thanks to all the wonderful yelp reviews. The cozy atmosphere welcomes you as you walk in, and it would be perfect for a romantic date night (like my husband and I) or if you wanted to kick back with a couple of friends. We had a reservation but still had to wait around 15 minutes which we were fine with. The renovations seem to be nearly done as there were big booths on the new side and there were people in the 1st one. We sat a a very cozy 2 person booth across from the bar. Our waiter was very attentive and gave us lots of recommendations.  The food... Incredible! Insane! Spectacular! We couldn't believe the freshness of this fish was like none we've EVER tasted in our lives. We enjoyed many of the creative dishes.  Our favorites were the Unagi poppers, Escolar Pearls, Orange Rush and Angry Crab.

Although the food was delicious there were a few things I found wrong with this place. Before I review I must state once again that the food is Very Very good. This place is just way to cramped. The minute you walk in you feel like there is no room to move. If u weigh over 140lbs don't even think of sitting towards the front. I know because my big behind was knocking stuff over left and right :/ Also, its BYOB which is totally cool but as far as anything to drink all they offer is warm water. This is definitely more of a date night place. Not bad but I don't think I will be back..

Fantastic, unique menu.  Come on an empty stomach and get the omakase for a glimpse at what this restaurant does best.  BYOB.

Service was great.  They gave us time to eat and enjoy.

Best sushi i've had in the city!  Absolutely phenomenal.  Went with 3 girlfriends and we all did the chef's choice menu, which left us all very full.  Service was great.  The place is very small and quaint, but cute.

Can't wait to go back!

This place was mind blowing and was sex in my mouth!  It was so good that I made another reservation while there for my first time for dinner.  Their menu is creative and not ordinary at all.  I highly recommend the Escolar Pearls rice spheres topped with scallions and super white tuna soaked in soy sauce, truffle oil, spicy mayo, and chili oil, then lightly seared = OMG!!!  Flaming Tuna Roll shrimp tempura, spicy tuna & avocado with seared tuna = OMG!  The entire menu sounds amazing and I can't wait to revisit and bring my sister here when she's visiting from Florida.

Kai Zan is such a relief for this neighborhood. Delicious, original, fresh Japanese food. Friendly service. BYOB. I found a spot at the sushi bar and ordered Omakase. Unbeatable. Small tastes from the deep menu, plus dishes not listed, but even better. Tasty sushi and sashimi. Inventive little bites of raw fish. Rich grilled skewers. Get in here!

The sushi was great and the $50/person omakase was excellent value for money.  Both my date and I really enjoyed the food.  Service was good (not great, but more than adequate).  I did notice that our first few dishes seemed rushed like they were trying to turn our table quickly (as others have mentioned), but the pace relaxed a bit for the rest of the meal and we didn't feel like they were trying to push us out.    

Some of the dishes in the omakase are fairly spicy.  They ask in advance if you have any preferences for the food, so speak up if you don't like heat.

DRINKS ARE BYOB.  There's a Dominick's on Chicago, just west of Damen, if you're in a rush and need to pick up a last minute beverage.  I had my cab stop there on the way and I was in and out with a chilled bottle of white in ~5 minutes.

This place is amazing!! Very creative and so fresh!  If you are looking for a place to have your typical dragon type roll's, this isn't the place.  The mussel's, angry crab, and orange rush are a few of my favorite things.  It can get pricey since you want to try everything so I wish they were still BYO. Service is great though and worth the $$ spent.

Lovely atmosphere; very pleasant and intimate. The three 2-person booths are great for dates. Service was cheerful and friendly!

FYI, while it is BYOB,  there is a $5 corkage fee for the table.

Each dish we ordered was spot-on-- unique, fresh, tasty. We greatly enjoyed the spicy tuna roll w/crispy shrimp tempura, and the "escolar pearls"-- bits of truffle- and soy- marinated escolar over small rice balls, with a tasty aioli and a little kick. There was a superb, refreshing, sea bass and cucumber roll special; I had never seen sea bass on a sushi menu, and the dish was delightful.

The dessert options were not the most exciting (green tea ice cream, cheesecake, coffee gelatin). We tried the coffee gelatin with bean curd and whipped cream-- the bean curd and cream combo was delicious and novel, but the gelatin was a bit odd and didn't really blend with the cream. (You know what would be awesome? Green tea ice cream affogato with the bean curd topping!)

A really nice spot, I look forward to going again!

Absolutely beautiful.  Lovely little cozy restaurant.  I am not even a huge sushi fan, so I just let my three girlfriends order, and absolutely loved everything I tasted.  Orange rush was my personal favorite.  Really is a must.

Small and cramped. That being said, this was one of the best meals I had all year. The omakase, which I had on several different occasions, was unbelievable. This is by far the best sushi spot I have ever been to.

Very delicious food.  The portion sizes were a bit misleading.  For example, in the same section of the menu were dishes that provided 2 "rolls" for $8 and the other 8 rolls for $8. You have to be careful when ordering.  

The pearls in the appetizers were delicious.  However, there were 4 small bites for $8.  

The food here tastes very delicious.  The chef gives recommendations on whether to eat with or without soy sauce.  The standard maki rolls were especially affordable (about $5-6 for 8 rolls).  I did wish that they had more specialty rolls.

The ambiance and decorations were great.  It is absolutely tiny in there (about 20 seats), but it was very nice in there. The service was great.  The girls constantly refilled the drinks.  Also, the servers memorized the daily specials.

Make sure you call ahead, even on a weekday!

First, thanks for opening a sushi spot near my house. Its just what this area needed. Second, thanks for serving amazing food at fair prices. I was in with my wife and 2 friends the other day. I must have tried 8 different rolls/dishes and wasn't let down by one of them.
The Danielle roll is amazing! The only negative is that I didn't bring enough booze with me as it's BYOB. No worries though, there is a great liquor store across the street!

I went for the tasting menu and I didn't regret it at all. Loved this place. The experience itself wasn't perfect but the food came pretty damn close. Here's my full review:

tastetestchicago.wordpre…
The best sushi I ever had! Everything is fresh and amazing! Nice presentation! Foods are out of my expectation! Absolutely I will go back again!! Sooooo good! The price is totally worth it!

I can't believe I have yet to write a review as I have now been here several times all the way from Arizona. I met the chefs when they were working at Kyoto and followed them to their own restaurant Kai Zan - I tell everyone I can about this great restaurant! The sushi is one of a kind - I highly recommend going and just letting the chefs feed you. It's BYOB so don't forget your wine - absolutely have the green monster roll and go now! You won't be disappointed!!

I'm in love with this place.  Best sushi in Chicago.  I used to say this about Ora in Andersonville and this place beats Ora.  We sat at the sushi bar and wanted everything we saw.  From the oyster shooter, pearls to the yummy goodness on the skewers, we enjoyed every bite.  Our server was laid back, friendly and real.  He wasn't the fake server that you see often.  Make sure you make a reservation.   The servings are small which is great because you can try so much of the menu.  Must try if you love sushi.

hands down, best sushi i've had in chicago.

like others have said, almost didn't want to share this news so that I can just enjoy it all to myself.

we shared a bunch of different things. some of the favs were the escolar pearls, orange crush, danielle, and the uni.

those were just the standouts - we absolutely loved everything.

go there. now. before all of chicago does.

In terms of quality, it's probably my second favorite Japanese restaurant in Chicago (Katsu still reigns supreme). As for bang for your buck? This is tops and not only when it comes to Japanese food. Reservations should be done far in advance and driving is sort of necessary to reach the location. Definitely recommend booking for a party of 6 people as you will get your own booth. You receive a lot of privacy but not at the cost of service; this place is remarkable at looking after your every need. Everyone in my party got the omakase meal which I highly recommend. At $60 per person, everyone in my group was full after their meal. By comparison, pricier places downtown (cough cough Roka Akor) can barely get you an entree for that price. The omakase set menu includes skewers, soup, appetizers, sushi rolls (3 full rolls between the 5 of us!), and sashimi. Everything was very fresh and tasty and I liked how it wasn't too modern of a take on traditional fare. I was so happy I finally had the chance to visit and look forward to returning

While the food was excellent - to be told we needed to get up from our seats because they needed them is completely unacceptable. If I am spending $250 for dinner - I DO not need to be rushed out.  There are plenty of great sushi options in Chicago.  Shameful that excellent food has to be ruined with awful service.

This was a mixed experience. Great booths and service. Prompter than many other sushi places I've seen - the meal didn't drag on at all. Most of the dishes were pretty good. But for a place of this caliber, pretty good just doesn't quite cut it. There was nothing I really disliked, but there was also nothing that truly blew me away. All the fish was fresh and prepared with attention. Kai Zan simply doesn't live up to its billing and can't match some of the other places that focus on this style (such as Cherry in NYC).
Some of the best sushi I've had in Chicago.  We got the Chef's Special, which was excellent.  But now we want to go back for some straight up nigiri.  And, BYOB!
Incredible - didn't care for the shooters - but the omakase was great!
Amazing specialty roles and the dessert is delicious! Very intimate setting with great music and very kind staff. A great date spot

This restaurant is the "Schwa" of Japanese food.  Very inventive and eccentric: not the sterile ambiance of your typical Sushi place.  Service is at the pace of the restaurant, not yours -- all dishes are "meant to share" and therefore delivered in no predictable order. The servers are efficient , knowledgable and genuine. The food itself is great: our party of 6 had about 20 different items, all of which were hits  The BYO policy really helps keep costs reasonable.

The wait for our RESERVATION to be seated at a table both times was an hour; therefore, we have never had the pleasure of actually dining at Kai zan the two times we had reservations. During one of our times, the manager tried to chill our red wine while we waited for our table; we told her that you don't chill red wine, EVER. They will also rush out other people because they cannot plan accordingly so they will ruin any date night you potentially have here if they want to turn over the table. Their managers will tell you the wait is 10 minutes and 30 minutes later you still won't be seated.
This place is really fantastic!!  Great service, excellent food, good vibe....love it all!   (NOTE: this place is small so make a reservation!!)

The sushi was very good, but the service from the hostess completely got us started on the wrong foot.  I got there first of my friends & was not greeted with a "hello," immediately I was asked if I had a reservation.  Then was told there was no reservation under my friend's name, & that they had a table for us but that they needed it back at 9:00 PM.  Fine.  When my friend arrived, she was shocked to hear there was no reservation since they took her credit card # when she made it & said they'd charge for a no-show, &  she even had a saved voicemail from them confirming the reservation.  The hostess told her they found us a table, but that they'd need it back at 9:00 PM.  When the waiter came over to our table, he asked if we knew that they needed the table back at 8:45 PM.  Jeez.  Contrary to some other people, apparently, it doesn't elevate my dining experience to be treated like a bother.  I'm happy to spend my money elsewhere.

Ohhh amazing!  I consider myself a sushi junkie and this place has changed the way I see sushi forever.  The service is wonderful, the sushi,  while a little higher price than other places,  is soo delicious.  The angry crab is pure heaven. It's byob and not great for groups larger than 4-6 and I'd stick to 2-4. Definitely worth the trip no matter where your coming from but make sure you make a reservation, especially if you have a long drive.
Great service.  Ambiance was superior.   Get the Chef's Choice
Amazing. The booths are really nice and private. The service was quick and attentive. BYOB so that's another plus and the fish is extremely fresh and very flavorful. Highly recommended.

Holy Holy Holy amazing.  Really interesting flavor combos.  Cool vibe.  Great music. Tiny but cool looking booths.  We did a few specials on and off the menu,many of  the Kai Zan rolls and some apps.  Everything was perfect even on a busy Friday night.  We made reservations before we left for a future date.  I wonder if they will soon outgrow this space.  Serious talent.  Reminds me of Macku but more funky and spicy!

Amazing. I have been looking for a Sushi place to blow me away, and Kai Zan did it.  Everything we ordered was fresh, beautiful, and the flavors well balanced.  Nothing was just "ok" - every bite made us want more.  We were lucky enough to get a reservation at 1 (of the 2) 4 person tables and all did the chef chooses menu.  We all loved it and can't wait to go back!  Note this is a tiny place, seats 25 only.  Decor was also fantastic.

Overall, fresh, creative and very, very tasy. To cap it off I thought the value for money was spot on.

Well done, Kai Zan. Well Done.
Wow!!!!!!!!!!!! Fantastic Japanese food. Great service! Love the location. I will become a regular here!! :)
The Chef's Omakase tasting selection is insanely good for $60.  Everything here is incredible.  Can't wait to go back.

Fabulous!
Kai Zan is a very small place so be careful not to miss it when you are driving down the street! The sushi is amazing. It's so fresh and delicious. The escolar pearls are so freaking good. We also got the fried chicken as recommended by our server, Michelle (who was awesome). It was super juicy and not something expected at a sushi place but it was a delight! As a special, there were oysters with a quail egg which were also incredible. We did get one roll which was great but definitely loved and enjoyed the fish pieces much more.  We will for sure be back to this little gem!
This place is AMAZING!!!! You have to do the Chiefs Choice!! Everything was incredible!! Definitely coming back again!

The food was good but the experience I was bad I appriciate the sushi cheifs stand all day hard work. I think they have a great business though, the hours are open til 11pm friday, the hostess at the door when we just 2 people, arrived at10:45 informed they where calling last call ,well we disputed the hours. We drove into humbolt park neighborhood to specifically go there, she said she will ask and they let us in, I have been dieing to go there etc..... but that entrance made for a unwelcomed vibe, we should of left! The hostess was heard telling the chief "I told them we where closed". Too bad to conduct business like that is terrible.  Change the hours then.  Again that hostess was rude.
delicious, fresh, amazing, fabulous, can do no wrong.  go here for the best sushi in chicago!

The omakase menu here is easily the best, and by far the best priced sushi around. A true tasting of everything that they make, and not one of the courses was disappointing. Go with an appetite, because by the 10th course you'll be stuffed! The service is a little rushed, but I think that's because the restaurant is so small so they want to get people in and out, but that is the only negative thing I can say about the restaurant. Its a must for any out of town guests you want to take for a fancy (yet affordable) meal!

I thought it was great the first time I went there, but this is my 4th or 5th time here and it keeps getting better. This place is full of surprises.
The Green Monster is out of this world! Sea bass cucumber roll is unexpected and delicious. I could eat that all day long. If you haven't been here, you need to go!!

Really not sure what all the hype is about. Went last night with 5 other people. The service was decent, the ambiance/decor was meh, the food was just alright. We had the chef's tasting menu; everything tasted okay, but I wasn't blown away by the freshness of the fish. I felt that they were trying a little too hard to be modern and stylish, and weren't focusing enough of their attention on the fundamental aspects of the food. For example, I expect the rice to be sticky and not fall apart when I put the food between chopsticks. Little things that I would expect an apparent 4-star restaurant to get right simply weren't executed. I do not think that I'll be back.

The Omakase tasting menu is unbelievable. It's $60-$70 a person for 10-12 courses but easily worth it.  The food is creative, has a great assortment of fish throughout the meal, and each course is unique and interesting in its own way.  Our server was very knowledgeable and invested in our experience.  The restaurant itself is tucked away and a little difficult to find but beautiful inside. I'd definitely recommend for any type of special occasion. Arguably the best meal i've had in Chicago.
Hidden gem. Amazing.  And just when you thought it couldn't get any better....it's. BYO.

I really enjoyed my meal here. Tried most of what our waiter recommended, and really loved it all. Favorite was the angry crab. Husband liked the oyster shooters a lot. Small, cozy, like that it's byob. Still pricey, but you get quality fish and creative dishes so very worth it. Will be back!

get the omakase!
took the wifey out on a date night and we both went with the omakase.  definitely one of the best meals i've had in chicago.

well, what are you waiting for?
Very enjoyable meal. Dishes are creative and tasty (though not exceptionally refined).It is excellent for the price and quality ratio.

Easily the best sushi I've had in Chicago. I did the Omakase which overall was awesome. Started with the kumamoto shooter which was great. Then came the unagi popper which was unreal. Obviously anything fried is good, but this was even better than can be imagined (and I love eel). Following the popper was the Carpaccio japanese red snapper. The combination of the fish and oil and spices was perfect and tasty. The rest is a little bit of a blur as the items came a little too fast and started to pile up our table. We did have the biggest clam I've ever eaten. While it tasted good, it was a little too large for my friends to take. Some raw shrimp was also served up along with the fried heads which were oozing of gooey goodness. The meal ended with a couple rolls which were a little disappointing. I'm usually not a fan of the huge american sized rolls that you can barely fit in your mouth and these were almost along those lines and definitely way too much of them. One roll for the entire meal would've been nice along with a dessert. Oh well, maybe you have to specify, but since our waitress wasn't helpful at all it was hard to know what to do. Sometimes its nice to actually know what you are eating without having to ask. Add on the fact that they made us wait 30 mins for our table (which we had reserved) and then hurried us out (telling us to go to the bar across the street, which we had been told to go to previously while we waited for our reservation) the experience took a hit in the service department. But hey, no one's perfect...

I have been to macku, arami, mirai, japonais, sea dog, coast, butterfly. Kai Zan is the best. I felt like Arami was a similarly great sushi restaurant, but 3x the price. I have been to Kai Zan 5 or 6 times. I will keep going back. My one caveat to this review would be that everyone should try macku at least once. They have the most interesting sashimi and nigiri (but the rest of their menu is crap).
Great sushi.  Now serving wine. Cant wait to go back favorite neighborhood sushi in Chicago.

This place is amazing.  I've eaten sushi all over the east coast and west coast and this place is one of the best.  Odd location, but totally worth the drive.  We maybe should have had the omikase (maybe next time), but EVERYTHING we had was awesome.  Sashimi was so fresh - we had the sea bass, tuna, and yellowtail.  2 "pieces" each is lot more than you'd expect.  All the specials are fresh and very creative.  We just kept ordering and ordering more and more fresh fish.  Can't go wrong.  We will definitely be back!!  The ambiance is great for a romantic date (I wouldn't come here in a group) and it's byob!

Just don't get all the rave reviews. Is it good? Sure. Exceptional it is not. Came here after seeing a mention in Chicago magazine's top new restaurants article. Got the omakase. Very much in line with other Japanese places in Chicago where everything's covered in tobiko/spicy mayo/jalapeno/ponzu or some iteration thereof. The delicate flavor of the uni/oyster in the namesake shooters were drowned in pure ponzu (yes I just drank an entire shot glass of citrusy soy sauce, must...have...water) Spicy mayo everywhere! Favorites were escolar pearls and the salmon sashimi. Perhaps Chicago is not ready for the purity of unadorned fresh fish.

One of the best sushi Place in Chicago.  The chefs Melvin and Carlos are very creative and takes sushi to a whole new level.  If you truly want an experience just ask them to serve you their signature dishes, you will not be disappointed.  Every dish we had was fresh and absolutely delicious.  The place only seats 22 at a time so make sure you reserve early.  Definitely a must try for all you foodies!!!

Hard to find, but worth the effort. This restaurant oozes charm like no other. Its almost as amazing as the sushi. Our waitress was also wonderful,  so patient kind and always eager to answer any questions.  I will definitely be returning

Wow this was amazing. Angry crab definitely my favourite. Have the tasting menu OMAKASE or you will miss out. The eel was sensational even for people who don't usually order it. Funky electronic Koi at the entrance make you feel right at home. The shooters of oyster and scallops were a real treat - as advised make sure you chew for maximal impact. Seriously worth getting a cab from down town - makes me want to move to Chicago. BYO an added bonus. What's not to love?!

Hands down the best sushi I've ever had in my life...and believe me....I've had a TON of sushi. Love the decor. Staff is great. The green monster is a must have. I could eat one every day. I appreciate sushi that doesn't need soy sauce. The flavors are incredible. Love the maguro pearl appetizers. Highly recommend Kai zan to anyone in the Chicago area. Also appreciate that it's BYOB and there is plenty of free on street parking. I can't wait to go back again! Two BIG thumbs up.
Super food and friendly service. Unusual, artful, wow tasty. Love it. Wish I could give more star review like 10. Go.

we got the "chef's choice" which was mostly good ... there were some things I didn't care for : there was a shooter with a quail egg and raw oyster and some chile oil and some other things I can't remember. Our waiter told us to shoot the whole thing which was way too much to take .. I did't like all the raw textures together. I ate the seafood out of the serving dish, but left the quail egg. (I couldn't eat the raw egg) and it was a pretty awkward, b/c we were sitting at the bar, right in front of the chef's (owner I believe) who make the food and they seemed unhappy they I didn't eat it. I definitely got a weird vibe from that. Overall I didn't really like sitting at the bar, I felt like I was being watched what I ate pretty closely and they weren't the friendliest guys, which is fine, but it was just a strange vibe. Our waiter was very nice, and explained everything very nicely and recommend a nice wine and sake. I really enjoyed the nigiri, very fresh and there was also a mussel dish that was delicious. The food was fresh and the restaurant cozy but I just wasn't crazy about my experience. I prefer Arami. But definitely worth a visit.

You could definitely miss this place driving by, but well worth the effort to find it.  I am not exactly a sushi aficionado, but this was some of the best sushi I have had many years.  Go light on the soy sauce as the sushi is so good, you don't need it. A quaint, laid back place and a nice, cozy space....nice option for a couples.  I will be back.

Super cute restaurant, awesome atmosphere and some great dishes. I loved the oyster shooters and the white fish special (I forgot the name but you roll it yourself). The sushi honestly was good but not amazing. I preferred more of the non sushi dishes, as they were more creative. I do, however, plan to go back and try the omakase.

What a great place.  My girlfriends and I planned an outing here after one of them had previously been on a date at Kai Zan.  We did the omakase because it seemed to make the most sense and biggest bang for your buck.  I couldn't have been happier with the food.  Everything was delicious and had layers of flavor and texture. The angry crab and oyster shooters were among my favorite dishes, leaving me wanting more.  The service was okay but  they seemed unsure about what dishes were what and what was next.  The restaurant itself is teeny tiny, however they are planning on expanding.  Looking forward to my next visit.

Really great find.  Service was fair at best, but the Omasake we ordered came continuously and was spread out nicely.  My daughter's chicken teriyaki came out really slow, but it was the best CT I've ever tasted.  So was the sushi.  Really spectacluar.  The Poppers were a let down, deep fried and something you could eat in a bar.  Also, the mussel was very memorable; but other than that, the food and presentation and atmosphere was all first class.
I feel very lucky to have such a great sushi restaurant in the neighborhood. Everything  tastes amazing. Staff is friendly, right down to the owner checking in to see how everything was.

read closely. Kai Zan is hands down the BEST sushi restaurant (i've ever tried). i'm a california native and i know what fresh seafood/sushi taste like. this place shocked me bc i didn't expect to find any better sushi places than the ones in cali. went with a few friends and got the omakase. best money spent on food! service was great. environment was intimate. doesn't really matter who you come with bc you'll just want to shut-up, close your eyes and enjoy the food. it was that delicious!

Not sure if it was an anomaly tonight, but we had a 7pm reservation and were sat 20 mins late - no big deal.  We were sat at the sushi bar instead of a table - no big deal.  We spent $90.00 and paid the BYO corkage...no big deal.  The food was great...but about an hour and a half in, we were asked to leave to accommodate other reservations.  Serious faux pas.  If it was just an idiot tip hungry server then I understand but if management asked him to push us along, there's really no excuse.  It's 50/50 if we'll give dine-in another shot but we would definitely consider them for carry out.

Three weeks ago this was the best sushi in Chicago. We were excited to come back, sit at the Chefs table and get the omakase. Unfortunately, they have just performed a cheap expansion and can't keep up with all of the business. The 10 courses were mostly mediocre, the service was inattentive, our dietary restrictions were repeatedly forgotten and the chef never swung by for even a passing hello. Why would I trek out to Humboldt park for something slightly better than supermarket sushi?? This once adorable spot with meticulously delicious food is now only worth the visit if you live in the neighborhood.

I loved this place.  Everybody was really nice.  And the food was exceptional.  Cannot wait to go back.  [Please note: I have no affiliation whatsoever with this place, other than I just went there for the first time and loved it!]
The most amazing sushi/sashimi and service.  I'd love it if Kai Zan remained a hidden gem forever, but doubt it will - it's too delicious to stay under the radar!
Good sushi/ Asian fusion.  I'm happy it's in the neighborhood.  It's a little claustrophobic.

I'm tempted to say this place sucks so that I won't have to compete with others to get a table. But I want this place to succeed because it's SO DARN GOOD. When my husband looked at the menu, he wasn't excited to go here. He didn't think there was a good variety of sushi rolls. But, once we were there, it didn't matter. The best things we ate weren't traditional rolls with lots of rice and fillings. The best things were the sashimi, killer crab roll (no rice),and soba noddles. Every piece of fish was delicious. Also, the atmosphere is COOL! Intimate, great servers, cool/funky style/decor, BYOB...overall just awesome!
the omakase was absolutely delicious...the servers were polite and knowledgeable...will definitely go back

This is hands down, the best Sushi you will ever eat! I, like everyone else recommend the chefs choice. The first time I went, one of the courses was this shooter with a egg yolk in it and I was really afraid of it, the texture mostly! Wow was I wrong, the best way I can describe it is like silk going down your throat! It is truly amazing! How anyone could give less than 5 stars is crazy to me! Seriously, someone complained about waiting 10 minutes! And others complaining about the decor or having to sit at the bar! Seriously! When you get to eat Sushi like that, who cares where you sit! Focus on the food when you are reviewing. I have to say that I am really sad that someone recommended them for Check Please. Why would you do that? It is an amazing spot, a hidden gem that should be kept special. Now you have made in even harder to get in. If I could, I would give them 10 stars! I recommend them to a lot of my clients and have only gotten rave reviews from them all. One man actually lived in Japan for 15 years and said that the food at Kai Zan was better than any he had in Japan. The twins who own Kai Zan are my hero's! Thank you guys!
